Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution along a rod is governed by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity. We inspect the effects of applying a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to the initial temperature distribution \\(u(x, 0)\\).

Can we determine the initial condition \\(u(x, 0)\\) after observing \\(u(x, t)\\) at time \\(t = T\\) without knowing if the Fourier transform was applied initially?
Explanation: Without the knowledge if the initial condition was subject to a Fourier transform, any alterations due to the transform, especially in terms of phase and amplitude in the frequency domain, will make it impossible to accurately reconstruct \\(u(x, 0)\\) from \\(u(x, t)\\) as the inverse process will not simply retract.
